column2: P5JS - Painting with Sound - Part 2
What you'll do
Continue your quest to turn sound into visuals by adding color and more detection logic!
Hi there! I'm glad you're back, {{user_name}} - I've got something awesome to show you!

First things first - let's get back to the p5.js code editor. You can load your previous sketch (if you saved it at http://editor.p5js.org), or get back to where we left off: https://editor.p5js.org/madetohack/sketches/7djSSUEJ
Last time, we learned how to use our microphone to move elements on our screen.
This time we will learn how to detect loud sounds and use them to draw.
First we will need to move our background(150, 100, 200); to inside the setup() function.
Placing the background function inside setup tells the program to only paint the canvas once, allowing us to draw over it.
Next, let's add condition that says, if the microphone is louder than a certain volume, then draw a circle.
To do this, delete the line with circle(width/2,height/2,volume*100); and then...
... Replace that line with if (volume > 0.1) { (Press Enter to get a new line) circle(random(width), random(height), volume * 100); (Press Enter to get a new line) }
This condition says that if the volume value goes above 0.10 then draw a circle at a random X and random Y location. If the volume value is below 0.10, then no circle will be drawn.
Let's run this and see what happens.
Whoa, it looks like the screen filled up quickly.  Let's fix that.
Maybe we can add another condition that says if the volume hits an even louder value then repaint the background?
Below the last } you typed, make a new line, and type if (volume > 0.3) { (new line) background(150,100,200); (new line) }
Now, if we run the sketch again, you can see the background being repainted everytime the volume goes above 0.3!
Next, we can add some more color to bring this painting to life.
Let's create a statement that says if the volume goes above 0.2, then let's choose a random color to fill each circle.
We can use random() to pick a random number from 0 - 255 for each of our Red, Green and Blue values. But first, we need a variable to store each of these numbers.
At the top of our draw loop we will add the following line: let r = random(255);
Let tells our program that the letter r will now store a random value between 0 and 255. Every time the draw loop is run, a new number will be selected and stored in r.
Now let's add g and b with the lines: let g = random(255); and let b = random(255);
Now if we add the line fill(r,g,b); above our circle(random(width), random(height), volume * 100); then we will fill each circle drawn with a new randomly selected color.
If you add noStroke(); above the fill(r,g,b); line, then the black outline on each circle will go away.
Cool, we've learned how to detect louder elements. Next time, we'll add even more elements to the mix!
